A brilliant busy brain-stretching baffling and often tough year. Thanks to everyone who made it better, especially my ace =mc consulting/@mcNAFS colleagues @bernardrossmc @danaksegal + @jbellinghammc... + the much-loved + sadly missed @bluecanaryemma.

Thanks everyone.

And being part of the world's first #artsfundraising #behaviouralscience project. + speaking at @TheResAlliance #IFC2020 #DefiningTheNewNormal conference via @FundEverywhere + #ChangeForBetter #decisionscience symposium

Highlights: helping @mikrontheatre raise over ¬£50K from their fans; designing + delivering @BreakingTradUK's first crowdfunder, showing that people love them + will support; a 100% trusts record with @20StoriesHigh.

A big thanks + happy new year 
to @breakingtradition @kpprojectsCIC @SillyBureau @HmadeParade @phizzical @CALiverpool_ @redladder. It was a pleasure working with you all + look forward to more in 2021.

From a slightly different world: my work with @csminnovation continued, supporting them on their vision, mission + values & developing their first 3 year strategy. A privilege to be an honorary member of this special team.

In November, I was chuffed to be asked to help @unitytheatre #Liverpool with fundraising for their future vision. A remarkable organisation, committed to being more than its physical theatre building + truly working with communities.

In same town, Marsden W Yorks - @MarsdenJazz. Tough times for those guys but together we've found a way to pivot to a completely different way of working that's creative, innovative + beautiful. May 2021 be even better.

Now: @mikrontheatre. Pete + Marianne are so committed to what they do + so connected to their audiences/fans - it's totally inspiring. It was a real pleasure to support their successful ¬£50K+ crowdfunder in the summer. May they be back on the road+waterways v soon.

Next: those radical storytellers @20StoriesHigh - also in #Liverpool. The work they've done through 2020, supporting young people + communities, constantly innovating + working with deep compassion in challenging times. I love em.

#theatre #arts
First up: Becky Vipond + Clare Owens - visionary + compassionate founders of @squashliverpool, bravely + lovingly changing lives through food, nature + creativity.

I know for many, 2020 was a 'mare but it wasn't without it's joys, happiness, successes & moments of connection.

I want to give a big shout out to the amazing people + organisations I worked with last year, who are doing brilliant things to make the world better in lots of ways.

I am re-entering the Twitter arena after my seasonal break &, first things first (albeit a little tardy) may I wish you all:

A VERY HAPPY 2021

that gives you as much reason to stop, think + exclaim 'if this isn't nice, I don't know what is' as often as possible.

Hang in there.

@KerryHarker @BBCBreakfast Is right Kerry... my concerns exactly. I have others too (see my thread this morning if interested...)

It IS brilliant news & a major victory for our sector. Don't get me wrong.

But this govt has form on actually delivering on what it promises and a lot remains to be seen about how effective this rescue package will be when it comes to #savetheartsUK.

I remain optimistic...

6/6

Fourth: the amount.

¬£1.57bn seems a lot. It IS a lot. But it has to go round a huge sector with big needs.

Will it be enough? Who knows.

Also: will it stymie philanthropy with a 'by-stander effect', ie they're alright now, when the problem isn't solved by this ¬£¬£.

5/6

Third: mechanism & rationale for distribution.

Who decides who gets what? Will it be by application... or influence. Some arts orgs are in a better position to lobby for support than others (see above). Others are far more prominent than others.

It has to be fair. & quick.

4/6

Second: what constitutes 'culture' to this govt?

Again. There seems to be emphasis on venue-based orgs & 'high art' (for want of a better phrase). Galleries, ballet, opera, big museums. 

Yes, they need help. 

But to be effective this ¬£¬£ has to reach the small guys too. 

3/6

First: geography.

Every single example of an arts org mentioned by @OliverDowden on BBC this morning was not only in the South East of England... but was actually in LONDON.

It has to cover every corner of the UK & especially those where big ¬£¬£ philanthropy doesn't reach.

2/6

.@RishiSunak's #arts & #culture rescue package was a good way to end the weekend... and has enabled me to wake up this morning much more optimistic about the future of the UK arts sector. 

But I have some concerns.

1/6

@floschechter @NHM_London I understand that some museum folk might be like 'hmmm, this could be bad' but others will be 'this could be really interesting'. I will watch with interest... 

Good chatting with you!

@floschechter I get where you're coming from Florence. I think we should wait & see what he does. Ian Blatchford (whatever your opinion) was a banker & finance director before moving to the V&A and later SMG. He has transformed the Science Museum from risking irrelevance to being a powerhouse.
@floschechter @NHM_London I think you're making a lot of (negative) assumptions about someone you don't know about a job they are yet to do. That's all.

@floschechter @NHM_London ... I am saying that just because Doug is a 'businessman' doesn't mean that things will be worse. Current director of NHM is museum/conservation guy through and through, and poor decisions were made (imo).

@floschechter @NHM_London His PERSONAL values can be different to a company's values, even if he's the head of it. He's employed by them; he's not the founder.

& I am not saying that. You're suggesting that Doug's appointment heralds an inevitable dive into exploitation & unethical practice...
@floschechter @NHM_London ...in the gift they accepted and name they gave to the Great Hall.

@floschechter @NHM_London Different settings call for different methods.  Values adapt to fit context. Amazon & NHM are very different beasts (obvs). I've met him many times. I don't think his values (different to Amazon's) will be detrimental to NHM. 

They've already shown their values are 'flexible'...

@floschechter @NHM_London I am not sure I agree on the motivations behind his appointment. As @loobilou said yesterday: Doug cares. He was instrumental in preventing the closure of the National Media Museum in Bradford. I think his experience on museum boards, political nous & business acumen count here.
@floschechter @NHM_London It's also worth noting that Amazon primarily makes so much money by selling absolutely shitloads of 'stuff'.

@floschechter @NHM_London A museum can, I think, be made more profitable through delivering an extraordinary visitor experience, driving repeat visits and, yes, by becoming more entrepreneurial... that's what I think will happen here, rather than driving down working standards & wages.

I may be wrong...

@floschechter @NHM_London I'm not sure you can make the leap that Gurr will 'import' Amazon working practices to a national museum. It doesn't really follow. He may not have worked in a museum before, but Doug has led them as chair of both trustees and advisory boards.

@SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma I didn't feel patronised Sarah, don't worry.

@DavidBurgessFR @SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma Of course it isn't. I was neither surprised nor disheartened by it. For 1, 'the arts' as a thing is nowhere near as motivating as specific orgs, and 2 - people are naturally going to order things differently during crisis.

MC understandably present their work as 'life or death'.

@DavidBurgessFR @SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma In fact, all 3 of the images evoked the bottom 3 in the About Loyalty research... arts, sport, religion.

Isn't this ad another reminder that we arts fundraisers need to get way smarter about making our case - rather than taking umbrage at other orgs v effective fundraising? https://t.co/NXhjppqxyQ

@DavidBurgessFR @SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma It's interesting in the light of the recent sentiment analysis that placed 'the arts' (note: not theatres, museums etc but an amorphous blob of artsness) as 'least important' in donors minds right not.

I wonder if MC created this ad with that in mind to tap into the 'mood'.
@SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma I am acutely aware of that.  I just don't read it the same way as you, I don't think.

@SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma But they are presenting theatre as an activity of 'normal life', along with sport and weddings, aren't they? Things that can be paused. They are not saying they don't matter.

If that was the case, all those people with weddings cancelled would be really pissed off by this too.
@SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma Or, come to see the ballet rather than the theatre? Or this film rather than this one? Or choose this restaurant over another?

@SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma In which case, wouldn't that 'implied hierarchy' be about trying to convince potential supporters that one is more important/deserving than another. Isn't that what we're all in the business of? Answering the question: "why should I give to you?"

@SarahABGee @mariecurieuk @bluecanaryemma My understanding of supporter psychology is: this won't stop people who do/want to support 'the arts' from doing so. 

Marie Curie+'insert favourite arts org here' aren't fishing in the same pool.

Those that support the arts give to Marie Curie too. It's not one or t'other.

I think it's honest + not seeking to cause division.

Illness/death can't press pause: other things can.
